online.game
Class commonCanvas

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Canvas
          online.common.exCanvas
              online.game.commonCanvas
All Implemented Interfaces:
Config, CommonConfig, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, DeferredEventHandler, ImageLoader.ImageConsumer, ImageLoaderProtocol, MenuParentInterface, MouseClient, RepaintManager.RepaintHelper, SimpleObserver, SizeProvider, UniversalConstants, CanvasProtocol, OnlineConstants, PlayConstants, sgf_names, ViewerProtocol, ViewGameProtocol, VncEventInterface
Direct Known Subclasses:
CheckerGameViewer, HexGameViewer
public abstract class commonCanvas
extends exCanvas
implements PlayConstants, ViewerProtocol, CanvasProtocol, sgf_names

This class extends exCanvas and provides a bunch of services for the individual game's Viewer class. Many of the requirements of ViewerProtocol are implemented here, and will not needs to be done by the game's subclass.
The main services are

  • a history of moves in the game
  • a "VCR cluster" of forward-back controls to view the game history.
  • mouse handling
  • repaint management
  • some standard option menus
  • debugging aids for screen layout and performance
  • a run loop

    See Also:
    exCanvas, Serialized Form

     void setControlToken(boolean val, long timeStamp)
              set ownership of the control token, with the timestamp if it's pending false,0 means we are relinquishing control false,nnn means we have requested control true,nnn means we have received acknowlegement of our claim of control if nnn isn't the same as controlToken, then there is a control fight going on and we shouldn't claim control even if the val is true The original communications to support this used client level message, either CONTROL or NOCONTROL to signal who was permitted to make moves.

    Field Detail

    robot

    public OnlineConstants.Bot robot

    isPassAndPlay

    public boolean isPassAndPlay

    animating

    public boolean animating
    animating is true while we are animating replay of a whole game, triggered by the |> button on the vcr panel.

    masterAnimationSpeed

    public double masterAnimationSpeed
    this is the value associated with the slider that appears during "movie" replays. When establishing individual animation steps, multiply time by masterAnimationSpeed

    started

    public boolean started

    boardRect

    public java.awt.Rectangle boardRect
    this is a standard rectangle of all viewers - the rectangle that contains the board. Your setLocalBounds(int, int, int, int) method still has to position this rectangles.

    stateRect

    public java.awt.Rectangle stateRect
    this is the standard rectangle for the current game state/action to take which is usually placed on top of the board rectangle

    noChatRect

    public java.awt.Rectangle noChatRect
    this is a standard rectangle of all viewers - the rectangle that contains the hide chat icon. Your setLocalBounds(int, int, int, int) method still has to position this rectangles.

    viewsetRect

    public java.awt.Rectangle viewsetRect
    common rectangle to hold the view selection rectangle

    fullRect

    public java.awt.Rectangle fullRect
    this is a standard rectangle of all viewers - the rectangle that contains the board. Your setLocalBounds(int, int, int, int) method still has to position this rectangles.

    reviewOnly

    public boolean reviewOnly
    normally, the game record is considered immutable during a game, but becomes mutable by the players after the game is over. What starts as a regular game is never mutable by spectators. What starts as a game review is mutable by everyone.

    mutable_game_record

    public boolean mutable_game_record
    true if the game record is generally mutable by someone. The distinction between this and allowed_to_edit is that spectators after a game are not allowed to edit.

    Digest

    public long Digest()
    this provides the game state, digested as a unique integer, for the game controller for fraud detection (the fraud being to play the same game over and over to inflate your score). It's used at midgame as well as endgame, to uniquely identify this game.

    hasExplicitControlToken

    public boolean hasExplicitControlToken()
    true if we have the control token. This should be used during normal play, when operations are strictly synchronous.

    Specified by:
    hasExplicitControlToken in interface ViewGameProtocol
    Returns:
    a boolean

    setControlToken

    public void setControlToken(boolean val,
                            long timeStamp)
    set ownership of the control token, with the timestamp if it's pending false,0 means we are relinquishing control false,nnn means we have requested control true,nnn means we have received acknowlegement of our claim of control if nnn isn't the same as controlToken, then there is a control fight going on and we shouldn't claim control even if the val is true The original communications to support this used client level message, either CONTROL or NOCONTROL to signal who was permitted to make moves. This proved to be unreliable because of real-time lags. The new protocol uses a server level "lock" request, which depends on the clients relinquishing the lock in a timely manner.

    Specified by:
    setControlToken in interface ViewGameProtocol

    setEditable

    public void setEditable()
    this is called by the game controller when the game is over and scoring activity has completed. It's now safe to let the players edit and rehash the game.

    currentRobotPlayer

    public commonPlayer currentRobotPlayer()
    locate a player which may be an active robot. This is used in the user interface to attach auxiliary display boards and also to find candidates to start, stop, or return moves. THe default will always return the current player, but in games with simultaneous actions, this method can be overridden to return a non-current player which is a robot.

    Returns:
    a player (which might or might not be a robot)

    doMouseTracking

    public void doMouseTracking(commonPlayer player,
                            java.lang.String zone,
                            int inx,
                            int iny,
                            int ino)
    Description copied from interface: ViewGameProtocol
    Record the latest mouse tracking information about the player (or spectator). only remembering, no other action, should occur. By convention, record nothing if player happens to be self. Also by convention, if inx is >=0 it reflects an object begin moved by the player, and all the other players should be set to not be moving. By convention, there is at most one moving object in the game at any time.

    Specified by:
    doMouseTracking in interface ViewGameProtocol
    Parameters:
    player - the player, or spectator.
    zone - default "on" "board" or "off", or whatever means something to your viewer
    inx - encoded x coordinate
    iny - encoded y coordinate
    ino - if >=0 represents an object being moved.

    UndoStep

    public void UndoStep(int target)
    move the view of the game history back to a particular step. The default inplementation does this the simplest and dumbest way, by calling "doWayBack()" and then stepping forward. For most circumstances this should be fine. You can override this method with a fancier or smarter UNDO if needed.

    doWayBack

    public void doWayBack(replayMode mode)
    move the view of the game history all the way back to the beginning. This could be implemented cleverly, but the simple and reliable method is to just reinialize the board.

    performStandardActions

    public boolean performStandardActions(HitPoint hp,
                                      boolean miss)
    call this to do the system standard actions that may be associated with HitPoint. These include scrolling actions generated by the vcr controls, and "edit" and "done" buttons which use the default ids and so on. If "miss" is true, and the action is "HitNoWhere" then performReset is called. The "miss" functionality provides a "miss one click, do nothing, miss two clicks, reset" paradigm

    Parameters:
    hp -
    Returns:
    true if the reset action was not armed, but should be armed next time

    startBoardAnimations

    public void startBoardAnimations(replayMode replay,
                                 OStack<?> animationStack,
                                 int size,
                                 commonCanvas.MovementStyle groupMovement)
    start animations from animationStack. In this version, if there are multiple animations, depending on the value of "serially", they are all started at once, or they are chained from first to last. If serially, the last cell is the final hop where the chip lives and the animation hops from the first to last.

    Parameters:
    replay -
    animationStack -
    size -
    groupMovement -

    startAnimation

    public SimpleSprite startAnimation(cell<?> from,
                                   cell<?> to,
                                   Drawable top,
                                   int size,
                                   double start,
                                   double duration)
    start an animation step in the simplest way.

    Parameters:
    from - the source cell
    to - the destination cell
    top - the chip to draw
    size - the size of the chip (ie; squaresize)
    start - the start time in seconds relative to the start of this animated sequence (0=start of this animation sequence)
    duration - in seconds of this animation. If 0, scale to the distance moved
    Returns:

    PerformAndTransmit

    public boolean PerformAndTransmit(commonMove m,
                                  boolean transmit,
                                  replayMode mode)
    perform and optionally transmit a move, return true if ok. Note, it's tempting to do any "auto move" that is needed in the continuation of this method, but don't. Doing so may separate the "perform" from the "transmit" which will lead to other players seeing the events out of order. Instead, use the continuation of ViewerRun

    EditHistory

    public commonMove EditHistory(commonMove m)
    the contract of editHistory is to remove unnecessary elements from the game history, resulting in a tidy record that when replayed, results in a duplicate of the current state. This default method works by taking a game digest after every move, and assuming that if the game digest reverts to a previous value, it must be an undo back to that move. Scanning back stops with a MOVE_DONE

    Parameters:
    m -
    Returns:
    a move to be added to the history, or null

    EditHistory

                              boolean okSame)

    truncateHistory

    public void truncateHistory()
    called to set the current move as the end of the move history. This can be used in conjunction with rewindHistory(int) to rewind a game to a given position. and permanently undo the intervening moves.

    rewindHistory

    public void rewindHistory(int size)
    rewind the game to a given position, usually preliminary to calling truncateHistory()

    Parameters:
    size -

    popHistoryElement

    public commonMove popHistoryElement()
    call this from your EditHistory(online.game.commonMove) method to remove a superfluous element at idx. Note that this maintains both the move tree in the commonMove elements, and the History list which contains the current linear path to the current move in the tree. Usually idx is the current last move in the history, and usually it has no successors. This method works to remove elements that are not leaves of the tree, but that is not usually something you want to do. Routine use by EditHistory should always remove leaves.

    popHistoryElement

    public commonMove popHistoryElement(int idx)
    remove a history element without attempting to remove the effects from the digest. This is used by some games (ie; zertz) to remove moves out of order which are actually independent and can be done in either order.

    Parameters:
    idx -
    Returns:
    a commonMove

    removeHistoryElement

    public commonMove removeHistoryElement(int idx)
    remove a history element at an arbitrary index. Unlike popHistoryElement(), this also removes the effect from the board by unwinding and rewinding the board.

    Parameters:
    idx -
    Returns:
    the removed element

    AddToHistory

    public boolean AddToHistory(commonMove originalnewmove)
    add to the history, but also edit the current move in progress so we don't clutter the history with extra steps. This doesn't hurt anything, but it looks bad and makes the move slider slide. At the point we get there, the move has already been fully performed, so only the history vector itself is affected.

    Returns:
    true if the current move was added to history

                            java.lang.String filename)

    ViewerRun

    public void ViewerRun(int waitTime)
    Description copied from class: exCanvas
    this is the run loop for the window. All significant events should occur here. Actions due to network, mouse, or keyboard should be deferred and handled here. Canvas painting is also deferred and handles here.

    About the only thing that doesn't happen here is activity by robots to search for next moves.

    Specified by:
    ViewerRun in interface CanvasProtocol
    Overrides:
    ViewerRun in class exCanvas
    See Also:
    exCanvas.handleDeferredEvent(java.lang.Object, java.lang.String), exCanvas.repaintCanvas()

    MouseMotion

    public HitPoint MouseMotion(int eventX,
                            int eventY,
                            MouseState upcode)
    handle mouse motion. This is called in the run loop, not synchronous with the mouse events. The principle effect is to call your redrawBoard(java.awt.Graphics, lib.HitPoint) method with gc=null, for the purpose of locating what the mouse must be pointing to.

    performReset

    public void performReset()
    reset the state of the game back to the previous "done" state, if that is allowed, or back to the previous "pick" operation, if that is allowed. This is done by truncating the game record, and replaying back to the new end. Normally this is triggered by two missed clicks in a row, taken to indicate the user is confused about the state of the game.

    See Also:
    allowPartialUndo(), allowBackwardStep()

    fixed_move_baseline

    public boolean fixed_move_baseline()
    this should be overridden to return true when out-of-sequence moves will actually occur. The effect of "true" is that communications with the server are held to a baseline and the players are allowed to overwrite each other's view of the most recent move.

    Specified by:
    fixed_move_baseline in interface ViewerProtocol
    Returns:
    a boolean

    useStoryBuffer

    public void useStoryBuffer(java.lang.String tok,
                           java.util.StringTokenizer his)
    Description copied from interface: ViewGameProtocol
    interpret a history string as created by formHistoryString. The contract is to bring the local game into the same state as the game that created the string. This is used to give spectators the view of the game, and also to reconnect players that have been disconnected.

    Specified by:

    Specified by:

    verifyGameRecord

    public void verifyGameRecord()
    verify the game record is still correct by cloning the board and replaying it. This is intended to catch "editing errors" by editHistory, but may also catch cases where Digest() is not producing the same result. In the process this exercises a lot of the game machinery, so other latent bugs are likely to show up right away as errors thrown from verifyGameRecord
    To assist with certain phases of debugging, where all this replaying can be confusing, set DISABLE_VERIFY=true;

    calcSquareSize

    public double calcSquareSize(int width,
                             int height,
                             int chatHeight,
                             boolean wideFormat,
                             boolean tallFormat,
                             double CELLSIZE,
                             int ncols,
                             int boardcols,
                             double reserveCols,
                             int nrows,
                             int boardrows,
                             double reserveRows)
    calculate a larger "square size" to maximize the size of a board within a larger frame composed of cells. The nominal layout is that in tall mode, the whole width (less a reserve) is devoted to the board, in wide mode, the whole height (less a reserve) is devoted to the board, in normal mode all the other rows and columns are reserved.

    Parameters:
    width - the width of the whole window
    height - the height of the whole window
    chatHeight - the height of the chat area, excluded in wide mode
    wideFormat - true if this is the calculation for a wide format window
    tallFormat - true of this is the calculation for a tall format window
    CELLSIZE - the cell size for all the non-board elements
    ncols - the number of columns in the whole window
    boardcols - the number of columns that will be converted to squares
    reserveCols - the number of reserved columns in tall mode
    nrows - the number rows in the whole window
    boardrows - the number of rows that will be converted to squares
    reserveRows - the number of reserved rows in wide mode
    Returns:
    a double, presumably a somewhat larger than the cellsize
